item.title: A thin slice of nothing
item.description: In this video I show you what it looks like when you have a thin slice of vacum next to a high density material like glass. I talk about thin film interference and the different ways that you can see it with different materials.

media:content.media:title: A thin slice of nothing
media:content.media:description: In this video I show you what it looks like when you have a thin slice of vacum next to a high density material like glass. I talk about thin film interference and the different ways that you can see it with different materials.

item.title: Seeing myself for the first time in a true mirror
item.description: A true mirror shows your reflection without left-right reversal, revealing how you actually look to others and why it feels so unfamiliar at first.

item.title: This ancient technology makes things spin really fast
item.description: A demonstration of an ancient device reveals how simple physics can create extremely fast spinning motion, showing that clever engineering existed long before modern machines.

item.title: Why you shouldn’t add ashes to sugar
item.description: A science experiment shows what happens when ashes are mixed with sugar, explaining the chemical reaction and why this combination leads to unexpected results.

item.title: This lens can make objects invisible
item.description: A science experiment shows how a special lens bends light in a way that hides objects from view, explaining the physics behind this invisibility effect.

item.title: Endless bouncing balls
item.description: A physics demonstration shows how bouncing balls can appear to keep moving endlessly, explaining the energy transfer and motion behind the effect.

item.title: Fried water
item.description: A surprising experiment shows how water can appear to be “fried,” breaking down the science and chemistry that make this counterintuitive result possible.

item.title: Can magnets actually make you cold?
item.description: An experiment explores how magnets interact with energy and motion, creating effects that can make objects feel colder than expected.

item.title: Why can't these rings be separated?
item.description: Three colored rings appear impossible to pull apart, until the hidden geometry and physics behind the puzzle reveal how they can actually be separated.

item.title: This brick can soak up so much water!
item.description: A surprising test shows just how much water a brick can absorb, revealing the material’s hidden structure and the science behind its extreme porosity.

item.title: How hydrophobic water creates “dry water”
item.description: A fascinating experiment shows how water coated with hydrophobic particles behaves like a dry powder, revealing the surprising physics behind so-called “dry water.”

item.title: Can a car power itself with a windmill?
item.description: An experiment tests whether a windmill powered by a moving car could generate enough energy to run the vehicle, breaking down the physics and why this idea does or doesn’t work.

item.title: Splitting water molecules with bare hands?
item.description: An intriguing demonstration that appears to split water molecules using bare hands, followed by a clear explanation of the physics and chemistry actually at work behind the illusion.

item.title: How entropy can actually create order
item.description: A science experiment explores how entropy, often linked to disorder, can sometimes lead to structured patterns and organized behavior under the right conditions.

item.title: The simplest self-braking pulley
item.description: A hands-on physics experiment demonstrates how a basic self-braking pulley works, explaining the forces and friction that allow it to stop itself without extra mechanisms.

item.title: Can a spinning blade umbrella actually stop the rain?
item.description: A science experiment tests whether spinning blades can block falling rain, breaking down the physics of motion, air flow, and why this idea works or doesn’t.

item.title: Can steam really light a match?
item.description: A science experiment tests whether steam can generate enough energy to ignite a match, breaking down the physics and heat transfer behind the result.

item.title: Why do balls untwist?
item.description: A simple physics experiment with a basketball explains why twisted objects naturally untwist, revealing how tension, torque, and stored energy work together.

item.title: Can power lines really light a bulb in your hand?
item.description: A science experiment tests whether electrical induction from power lines is strong enough to light a bulb, explaining the physics behind what’s actually happening.

item.title: What happens when welded sand is crushed?
item.description: A physics experiment uses a hydraulic press to crush welded sand, revealing how extreme pressure changes its structure and behavior.
